title: Informational Text: Text Features

vocab.definition: Parts of a text that help you find and understand information, like headings, bold words, and captions.
A title at the head of a page or section of a book.
A short explanation under a picture or illustration.

teachingNotes: Create a 'text feature scavenger hunt.' Give students a list of features (e.g., 'a bold word,' 'a caption,' 'a heading') and have them find examples in a non-fiction book or article.

sample.question: What is a heading in a book?
expectedAny: A title for a section.

sample.question: Why do authors use bold words?
expectedAny: To show they are important.

sample.question: What does a caption tell us?
expectedAny: It explains a picture or photograph.

sample.question: What is the purpose of a table of contents?
expectedAny: To show where chapters or sections start.

sample.question: How do diagrams help readers understand a topic?
expectedAny: They show the parts of something.

sample.question: What kind of information can you find in a glossary?
expectedAny: Definitions of important words.

sample.question: Why are photographs included in informational texts?
expectedAny: To show what something really looks like.

truefalse.question: Headings tell the reader what a new section of text will be about.
A caption is a short sentence that explains a picture or diagram.
Words that are in bold print are usually not very important.
An index is found at the very front of a book.
Diagrams are drawings that show how things work or what their parts are.
A glossary is like a mini-dictionary for the book.
Text features are designed to help readers find and understand information more easily.

multiplechoice.question: A table of contents helps a reader by showing ___.
choices: the page numbers where chapters begin
all the pictures in the book

multiplechoice.question: Bold words in a text are usually ___.
An index at the back of a book helps you find ___.
choices: the exact page number for a specific topic

multiplechoice.question: Labels on a diagram are used to name the ___.
A sidebar or text box on a page usually contains ___.
A map is a text feature that shows ___.

fillintheblank.question: A ___ is a short description under a photograph that explains what it is.
expectedAny: caption

fillintheblank.question: Important vocabulary words are often written in ___ print to make them stand out.
expectedAny: bold

fillintheblank.question: The ___ at the beginning of a book lists the chapters and their starting page numbers.
expectedAny: table of contents

fillintheblank.question: If you don't know the meaning of a word, you can look it up in the ___.
expectedAny: glossary

fillintheblank.question: An ___ at the back of the book lists topics alphabetically and the pages where you can find them.
expectedAny: index

fillintheblank.question: ___ and charts help organize information into rows and columns.
expectedAny: Tables

fillintheblank.question: A ___ is a drawing with labels that shows the different parts of something.
expectedAny: diagram

shortanswer.question: How do headings and subheadings help you when you are reading?
expectedAny: They organize the text into smaller sections and tell you what each section is about.

shortanswer.question: Why are text features like bold words and glossaries important in non-fiction books?
expectedAny: They help you learn new vocabulary and understand the topic better.

shortanswer.question: What is the difference between a glossary and an index?
expectedAny: A glossary defines words, while an index tells you the page number where a topic is mentioned.

shortanswer.question: How can looking at pictures and captions help you before you even start reading the main text?
expectedAny: They give you clues about what the text will be about.

shortanswer.question: Name five different text features you might find in a science textbook.
expectedAny: Headings, captions, bold words, diagrams, glossary, index, table of contents

shortanswer.question: How do you use a table of contents to find information?
expectedAny: You look for the chapter or section you want to read and then go to the page number listed.

shortanswer.question: Why might an author use different fonts or text sizes in a book?
expectedAny: To show that some information, like a heading, is more important or to organize the page.
